title: Trevor Bissert
text:
This fall I began my PhD journey in the Developmental and Brain Sciences Program at the University of Massachusetts, Boston as a part of the Early Minds Lab. I’m working with my advisors Dr. Zsuzsa Kaldy and Dr. Erik Blaser, researching the development of working memory using pupilometry and eye-tracking methods with children.
Previously, I worked in the Labs of Cognitive Neuroscience at Boston Children’s hospital on projects investigating the development of executive functioning in US and Bangladeshi children using EEG and fNIRS neuroimaging methods and eye-tracking. I’m interested in the development of early cognitive mechanisms behind memory and attention and how they interact with the environment. My passion lies in methodology, using eye-tracking and neuroimaging methods for a multimodal perspective on cogntion.
In my free time I love trying new foods with my partner and traveling as much as we can. I’m also a plant parent to over 50 plant babies!

title: Current Projects
text: My first year project for my PhD is an adapted version of a shopping game investigating the individual differences in how children use their working memory alongside external resources. I’m curious about how much children choose to remember in various time conditions and how this strategy differs among individuals and is maintained over time.
